item.title: Paired T-Test
item.description: AKA dependent t-test: Dependent variable (DV): Scores being compared Measured on at least an interval level scale Often used to compare post-score to pre-score Independent variable (IV): The treatment or intervention Typical research question: Is there a mean difference between the post-score and pre-score? Also used to compare twins, couples, eyeballs, etc. 20 weeks of cognitive behavioral therapy -> Amount and severity of depressive symptoms Intervention -> Students' math proficiency Constraint induced movement therapy -> hand function One-group pretest-posttest design: O1 (pre) X O2 (post) One-group pretest-posttest design using a double pretest: O1 O2 X O3 One-group pretest-posttest design using a nonequivalent dependent variable: (O1 A, O1 B) x (O2 B, O2 B) The removed-treatment design: O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 The repeated-treatment design: O1 x O2 x O3 x O4 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples NR (Not Random) O1 X O2 NR (Not Random) O1 O2 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using a double pretest NR O1 O2 X O3 NR O1 O2 O3 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using switching replications NR O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 NR O1 O2 (O3) x O4 Untreated control group design dependent pretest and posttest samples using reversed-treatment control group NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) Nondirectional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly different from pre-score (µ1) H0: µ2 = µ1 vs. H1: µ2 ≠ µ1 Alternatively, in terms of mean difference: H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 The mean difference is the difference in pre- and post-scores, so a paired-sample t-test is identical to a one-sample t-test, testing the difference in scores against the hypothesized (test) value! Directional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly greater from pre-score (µ1). H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 Directional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly smaller than pre-scores (µ1): H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0 One Sample StatisticsOne-Sample Test For negative emotion change (hypothesized to decrease), the one-sample t-test is significant, t (33) = -2.393, p = .011. The mean difference is -0.20 (negative emotion decreased after watching the video). The 95% upper confidence limit -. 0585 below zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly smaller than 0). For positive emotion change (hypothesized to increase), the one-sample t-test is significant, t (33) = 6.448, p < .001. The mean difference is 1.06 (positive emotion increased after watching the video). The 95% lower confidence limit .7809 above zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly greater than 0). tobs = d ÷ sd-bar or d ÷ (sd ÷ √n) d is the mean difference and sd-bar is the standard error of the mean difference: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n sd is the standard deviation of the difference scores (i.e., like any other standard deviation only this one is computed from the difference scores rather than raw scores). n is the total number of pairs. Recall in one-sample t-test: tobs = ( - µ0) (s ÷ √n) Where is µ0? Given 𝛼 level, nondirectional or directional, and degree of freedom (df = n - 1), critical t can be found on the t-table (if df is available). Recall rejection region is outside of critical t('s) toward the tail (s). Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) or p < 𝛼 (SPSS) 𝛼 level is usually .05 (95% confidence level) Nondirectional: 100 (1 - 𝛼)% CI: ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sd-bar ÷ √n) To test greater (significant increase in post-scores): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% LCL: - tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar To test smaller (significant decrease in post-scores): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% UCL: + tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar DV data recorded as 2 variables (e.g., pre-score and post-score) in SPSS IV (treatment, intervention) is usually not recorded as a variable in SPSS Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test Move the two variables of interest (e.g., pre-score and post-score) to the paired variable 1 and variable 2. Notice the mean difference SPSS computes is variable 1 minus variable 2, so sometimes the sign of observed t can be confusing. However, you can easily figure out if the effect is positive or negative based on the descriptive statistics. I like to enter post-score as variable 1 and pre-score as variable 2 so I can see the change (positive or negative) from pre-score to post-score. Paired Samples StatisticsPaired Samples CorrelationsPaired Samples Test For negative emotion change: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n = .48742 ÷ √34 = .08359 tobs = d-bar ÷ sd = - .2000 ÷ .08359 = -2.393 For positive emotion change: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n = .95754 ÷ √34 = .16422 tobs = d-bar ÷ sd = 1.05882 ÷ .16422 = 6.448 Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to decrease (one-tailed test). H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0 Mean difference d-bar = - .2000, SD sd = .48742, sd-bar = .08359 tobs = -2.393, df = 33, p = .011 Since the p-value (. 011) is smaller than the 𝛼 level (. 05), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' negative emotion significantly decreased after watching the cat videos. Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to increase (one-tailed test). H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 Mean difference d-bar = 1.05882, SD sd = .95754, sd-bar = .16422 tobs = 6.448, df = 33, p < .001 Since the p-value is very small (< .001), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' positive emotion significantly increased after watching the cat videos. Cohen's d = d-bar ÷ sd-bar Recall Cohen's d for one-sample t-test: d = ( - µ0) ÷ s Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ±0.2: Small effect d = ±0.5: Medium effect d = ±0.8: Large effect Paired Samples Effect Sizes For negative emotion change, Cohen's d (- 0.410) suggests a small to medium effect. For positive emotion change, the effect size (d = 1.106) is quite large. The pre-video and post-video negative emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 4.80 (SD = 0.926) and a post-score mean of 4.60 (SD = 1.028). Thus, negative emotion changed by -0.20 (decrease) after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly smaller than zero (significant decrease after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly lower than the pre-score, t(33) = -2.393, p = 0.011. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was -0.410. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small to medium effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the negative emotion significantly decreased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests about 0.4 standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The pre-video and post-video positive emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 3.76 (SD = 0.998) and a post-score mean of 4.82 (SD = 1.014). Thus, positive emotion increased by 1.06 after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly greater than zero (significant increase after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly higher than the pre-score, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was 1.106. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a large effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the positive emotion significantly increased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests more than one standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The results from the pre-test (M = 13.5, SD = 2.4) and post-test (M = 16.2, SD = 2.7) memory task indicate that the presence of caffeine in the bloodstream resulted in an improvement in memory recall, t(19) = 3.1, p = .006. There was a significant increase in the volume of alcohol consumed in the week after the end of semester (M = 8.7, SD = 3.1) compared to the week before the end of semester (M = 3.2, SD = 1.5), t(52) = 4.8, p < .001 How to Report the Result of a T-Test (APA style) If you're hypothesis testing, restate your hypothesis. If your t-test is one-tailed, you need to say so. It's preferred to report the exact p-value unless it's smaller than .001. You need to state your alpha level (usually .05) early in the results section. If your p-value is smaller than .001, it's conventional simply to state p < .001 (NEVER report p = 0) Remember to drop the leading 0 from the p-value. No need to provide a formula for observed t in your paper. Observations are from a random sample, and the scores are independent of each other. Dependent variable of interest is measured on at least an interval scale. Difference scores (d's) are normally distributed. Typically considered robust to violations of non-normality, especially for big sample (n > 30) If one of the samples is highly skewed (particularly for a one-tailed test), a lot of error will tend to be built into the difference scores. Other non-parametric analyses would be better alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
item.description: Also known as Simple Linear Regression (SLR)
item.guid: Glossary/Research Methods/Quantitative Data Analysis/Ordinary Least Squares (OLS).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: One-Way Independent ANOVA
item.description:
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
Dependent Variable (Y; continuous)
Independent Variable (X; categorical, grouping variable) It is equivalent to a t-test but can have more levels (groups tested at once). Used to compare means of two or more independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. Testing whether different teaching methods (Group A, B, C) produce different average exam scores. State the null and alternative hypotheses: H0: µ1 = µ2 ... (µ represents the population mean for each group) H1: µ1 ≠ µ2 ... (at least one mean is different)
Click Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Explore > Tests for Normality (Shapiro-Wilk Test, Q-Q Plot, Histogram) Go to Analyze > General Linear Model > Univariate
Move your Dependent Variable (e.g., exam scores) to the Dependent Variable box.
Move your Independent Variable (grouping variable) (e.g., teaching method) to the Fixed Factor(s) box. Click Options, check Descriptive Statistics and Homogeneity Tests. Click Continue. Click OK for output and Paste for syntax editor. Interpretation: Since p = 0.12 (p > 0.05), the assumption of equal variances is met. Interpretation: The significant F (F (2, 57) = 5.43, p = 0.008) indicates that at least one group mean is significantly different. "A one-way ANOVA was conducted to examine the effect of teaching method on exam scores. Results indicated a statistically significant difference among the groups, F (2, 57) = 5.43, p = 0.008. Levene's test confirmed the assumption of homogeneity of variances, p = 0.12. Post hoc comparisons using Tukey's HSD indicated that Group A scored significantly higher than Group C (p < 0.05)." Compute SST SSE = ∑ (Yi - Y-hati)2
Compute the Degrees of Freedom Degrees of Freedom Between Groups dfBG = k - 1 (k is the number of levels / groups / conditions) (between groups) Degrees of Freedom Within Groups (Error) dfE = N - k (N is the total number of participants in a study) (within group / error) Sums of Degrees of Freedom dfTot = N - 1 Compute F Ratio
Variance between groups (proportion of variability in Y explained by X) Variance within groups (proportion of variability in Y unexplained by X) MSBG (Mean square, instead of getting the sum of squares of error, we will be getting the mean square; BG: between group; E: error or within group)
Values for the F statistic should all be positive. F = 1 means no mean difference because the between and within group variabilities would be the same. The higher your F, the greater change of it being significant (would mean there is a much higher variability between groups than you see within groups) Complete F Table Compare the calculated F-value against the F-crit value If F-value is greater than F-crit then you can say there is a statistically significant difference between the means of the groups. When looking at the F-crit table, the df between is horizontal and df within is vertical. Make a Decision Write up the F-values (i.e., F (1,10) = 41.227, p < .001). A bar graph can be used to visually depict the differences as well. Example Language: "We conducted a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) to examine whether there was a mean difference of depression scores between subjects who were diagnosed with depression and who were not. The ANOVA results showed that there was a statistically significant mean difference between the two groups (F (1,22) = 117.42, p < .001)." The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to determine whether there are any statistically significant differences between the means of three or more independent (unrelated) groups. The one-way ANOVA compares the means between the groups you are interested in and determines whether any of those means are statistically significantly different from each other. Specifically, it tests the null hypothesis:
Where µ = group mean and k = number of groups. If, however, the one-way ANOVA returns a statistically significant result, we accept the alternative hypothesis, which is that there are at least two group means that are statistically significantly different from each other. The one-way ANOVA is an Omnibus test statistic, and cannot tell you which specific groups were statistically significantly different from each other, only that at least two groups were. To determine which specific groups differed from each other, you need to use a post hoc test. It is used to test research questions and hypotheses where you want to compare the means of three or more groups on a single dependent variable. You are asking if there is a significant difference between the groups based on a single categorical independent variable with multiple levels. If you are dealing with individuals, you are likely to encounter this situation using two different types of study design: One study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then randomly split this group into three or more smaller groups (i.e., each participant is allocated to one, and only one, group). You then get each group to undertake different tests (or put them under different conditions) and measure the outcome/response on the same dependent variable. For example, a researcher wishes to know whether different pacing strategies affect the time to complete a marathon. The researcher randomly assigns a group of volunteers to either a group that (a) starts slow and then increases their speed, (b) starts fast and slows down or (c) runs at a steady pace throughout. The time to complete the marathon is the outcome (dependent) variable.
A second study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then split them into groups based on some independent variable. Again, each individual will be assigned to one group only. This independent variable is sometimes called an attribute independent variable because you are splitting the group based on some attribute that they possess (e.g., their level of education; every individual has a level of education, even if it is 'none'). Each group is then measured on the same dependent variable having undergone the same task or condition (or none at all). For example, a researcher is interested in determining whether there are differences in leg strength between amateur, semi-professional and provessional rugby players. The force/strength measured on an isokinetic machine is the dependent variable.

Every time you conduct a t-test there is a chance that you will make a Type I Errors. This error is usually 5%. By running two t-tests on the same data you will have increased your chance of "making a mistake" to 10%. The formula for determining the new error rate for multiple t-tests is not as simple as multiplying 5% by the number of tests. However, if you are only making a few multiple comparisons, the results are very similar if you do. As such, three t-tests would be 15% (actually, 14.3%) and so on. These are unacceptable errors. An ANOVA controls for these errors so that the Type I Errors remains at 5% and you can be more confident that any statistically significant result you find is not just running lots of tests. When you choose to analyze your data using a one-way ANOVA, part of the process involves checking to make sure that the data you want to analyze can actually be analyzed using a one-way ANOVA. You need to do this because it is only appropriate to use a one-way ANOVA if your data "passes" six assumptions that are required for a one-way ANOVA to give you a valid result.
Your dependent variable should be measured at the interval or ratio level (Interval Variable and Ratio Variable) (i.e., they are Continuous Variable; IQ score, exam scores, weight, etc). The dependent variable is normally distributed in each group that is being compared in the one-way ANOVA (technically, it is the residuals that need to be normally distributed, but the results will be the same).
For example, if we were comparing three groups (e.g., amateur, semi-professional, and professional rugby players) on their leg strength, their leg strength values (Dependent Variable) would have to be normally distributed for the amateur group of players, normally distributed for the semi-professionals and normally distributed for the professional player. You can test for normality in SPSS.
Testing for Normality There is homogeneity of variances. This means that the population variances in each group are equal. If you use SPSS Statistics, Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variances is included in the output when you run a one-way ANOVA in SPSS Statistics.
Independence of Observations. This is mostly a study design issue and, as such, you will need to determine whether you believe it is possible that your observations are not independent based on your study design.
Your Independent Variable should consist of two or more categorical, independent groups. Typically, a one-way ANOVA is used when you have three or more categorical, independent groups, but it can be used for just two groups (but an Independent Samples T-Test Independent Samples T-Test is more commonly used for two groups) Example independent variables that meet this criterion include ethnicity (e.g., 3 groups: Caucasian, African American, and Hispanic), physical activity level (e.g., 4 groups: sedentary, low, moderate, and high), profession (e.g., 5 groups: surgeon, doctor, nurse, dentist, therapist) and so forth.
You should have Independence of Observations, which means that there is no relationship between the observations in each group or between the groups themselves. For example, there must be different participants in each group with no participant being in more than one group. This is more of a study design issue than something you can test for. If your study fails this assumption, you will need to use another statistical test instead of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., a repeated measures design). There should be no significant outliers. Outliers are simply data points within your data that do not follow the usual pattern (e.g., in a study of 100 students' IQ scores, where the mean score was 108 with only a small variation between students, one student had a score of 156, which is very unusual, and may even put her in the top 1% of IQ scores globally). The problem with outliers is that they can have a negative effect on the one-way ANOVA, reducing the validity of your results.
Your Dependent Variable should be approximately normally distributed for each category of the Independent Variable. We talk about the one-way ANOVA only requiring approximately normal data because it is quite 'robust' to violations of normality, meaning that assumption can be a little violated and still provide valid results. You can test for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk test of normality, which is easily tested for using SPSS Statistics.
There needs to be Homogeneity of Variances. You can test this assumption in SPSS Statistics using Levene's test for homogeneity of variances. If your data fails this assumption, you will need to not only carry out a Welch ANOVA instead of a one-way ANOVA, which you can do using SPSS Statistics, but also use a different post hoc test.
The one-way ANOVA is considered a robust test against the normality assumption. This means that it tolerates violations to its normality assumption rather well. As regards the normality of group data, the one-way ANOVA can tolerate data that is non-normal (skewed or kurtotic distributions) with only a small effect on the Type I Errors rate. However, platykurtosis can have a profound effect when your group sizes are small. This leaves you with two options: Transform your data using various algorithms so that the shape of your distributions become normally distributed Choose the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis H Test which does not require the assumption of normality. There are two tests that you can run that are applicable when the assumption of homogeneity of variances has been violated. Welch Brown and Forsythe test. Alternatively, you can run a Kruskal-Wallis H Test. For most situations, it has been shown that the Welch test is the best. Both the Welch and Brown and Forsythe tests are available in SPSS. A lack of independence of cases has been stated as the most serious assumptions to fail. Often, there is little you can do that offers a good solution to this problem. Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-Way ANOVA

Add Dependent Variable to the Dependent List box, and add the Independent Variable to the Factor box. Click Options. Check the box for Means Plot, then click Continue. Click OK when finished. ONEWAY Sprint BY Smoking /PLOT MEANS /MISSING ANALYSIS.
The Dependent Variable. This is the variable whose means will be compared between the samples (groups). You may run multiple means comparisons simultaneously by selecting more than one dependent variable.
The Independent Variable. The categories (or groups) of the independent variable will define which samples will be compared. The independent variable must have at least two categories (groups), but usually has three or more groups when used in a One-Way ANOVA. Specify contrasts, or planned comparisons, to be conducted after the overall ANOVA test. When the initial F-test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, contrasts are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you have specific hypotheses that you wish to test. Contrasts are decided before analyzing the data (i.e., priori). Contrasts break down the variance into component parts. They may involve using weights, non-orthogonal comparisons, standard contrasts, and polynomial contrasts (trend analysis).
Request post hoc (also known as multiple comparisons) tests. Specific post hoc tests can be selected by checking the associated boxes.
When the initial F test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, post hoc tests are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you do not have specific hypotheses you wish to test. Post hoc tests compare each pair of means (like T-Test s), but unlike T-Test s, they correct the significance estimate to account for the multiple comparisons.
Multiple comparisons options that assume homogeneity of variance (each group has equal variance). By default, a 2-sided hypothesis test is selected. Alternatively, a directional, one-sided hypothesis can be specified if you choose to use a Dunnett post hoc test. Click the box next to Dunnett and then specify whether the Control Category is the Last or First group, numerically, of your grouping variable. In the Test area, click either < Control or > Control. The one-tailed options require that you specify whether you predict that the mean for the specified control group will be less than (> Control) or greater than (< Control) another group. Multiple comparisons options that do not assume equal variances. The desired cutoff for statistical significance. By default, significance is set to 0.05. Clicking Options will produce a window where you can specify which Statistics to include in the output (Descriptive, Fixed and Random Effects, Homogeneity of Variance Test, Brown-Forsythe, Welch), whether to include a Means Plot, and how the analysis will address Missing Values (i.e., Exclude cases analysis by analysis or Exclude cases listwise). Click Continue when you are finished making specifications.
You will have calculated the following results or obtained them from SPSS.
"There was a statistically significant difference between groups as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021)." this is all you will need to write for the one-way ANOVA per se. However, you will probably also want to report means ± Standard Deviation (SD) s for your groups, as well as follow up a statistically significant result with a post hoc test. The general form of writing the result of a one-way ANOVA is as follow:
You should not report the result as 'Significant difference,' but instead report it as 'statistically significant difference.' this is because your devision as to whether the result is significant or not should not be based solely on your statistical test. Report the result of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., 'There were no statistically significant differences between group means as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 1.397, p = .15)'). Running a post hoc test is usually not warranted and should not be carried out. You need to report your results. You then need to follow-up the one-way ANOVA by running a post hoc test. You need to perform the same procedures as above, but add into your results section that this assumption was violated and you needed to run a Welch F test. ANOVA test tells you whether you have an overall difference between your groups, but it does not tell you which specific groups differed - post hoc tests do. Because post hoc tests are run to confirm where the differences occurred between groups, they should only be run when you have a shown an overall statistically significant difference in group means (i.e., a statistically significant one-way ANOVA result). Post hoc tests attempt to control the experiment-wise error rate (usually alpha = 0.05) in the same manner that the one-way ANOVA is used instead of multiple t-tests. Post hoc tests are termed a posteriori tests; that is, performed after the event (the event in this case being a study). There are a great number of different post hoc tests that you can use. However, you should only run one post hoc test - do not run multiple post hoc tests. For a one-way ANOVA, you will probably find that just two tests need to be considered. If your data met the assumption of homogeneity of variances, use Tukey's honestly significant difference (HSD) post hoc test. Note that if you use SPSS Statistics, Tukey's HSD test is simply referred to as 'Tukey' in the post post hoc multiple comparisons dialogue box. If your data did not meet the homogeneity fo variances assumption, you should consider running the Games Howell post hoc test.

item.title: Multivariate Model
item.description: Any of several methods for examining multiple (three or more) variables at the same time - usually two or more independent variables and one dependent variable.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Mahalonobis' Distance
item.description: Identifies the distance of cases from the Mean (s) of Predictor (s). Extreme cases in multivariate space are found via a cut-off point (critical value of chi-square).
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Linearity
item.description: Variables must be linearly related to each other Can be visually inspected via bivariate scatterplots (but be aware of limitations of mean averages based on Likert-type scales) Relations may be quadratic or cubic Testing Linearity
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Least Squares Method
item.description:
Method of minimizing overall error in a particular model by producing estimates that have the least ' Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) ' (SSE = the sum of squared residual effects). Residual effects Unexplained variation in the outcome variable Error can be positive or negative, but negative residual is illogical, so we square the residuals. Best estimates for the b's are the one's that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. The model with the smallest SSE will be the best fitting model.



The model with the smallest Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) will be the best fitting model
Least squares regression line
These values will always give us the smallest overall error, compared to any other line draw through the set of points.
item.guid: Glossary/Research Methods/Quantitative Data Analysis/Least Squares Method.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Interval Variable
item.description: Interval variables are variables for which their central characteristic is that they can be measured along a continuum and they have a numeric value. For example, temperature measured in Celsius or Fahrenheit. So the difference between 20 degrees Celsius and 30 degrees Celsius is the same as 30 degrees Celsius to 40 degrees Celsius. However, temperature measured in degrees Celsius is NOT a RATIO variable.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Forward Stepwise Regression
item.description: Most predictive variables are added first
item.guid: Glossary/Research Methods/Quantitative Data Analysis/Forward Stepwise Regression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Hierarchical Multiple Regression
item.description: Predictors are added in theory-driven blocks (e.g., social-ecological models) A series of multiple-regression are performed, with each block being added to the next until all variables are included The final block of hierarchical multiple regression = simultaneous multiple regression Very useful to look at change in R-squared for each variable or blocks of variables Squared semi-partial correlation provides the unique variance explained by a given variable.
item.guid: Glossary/Research Methods/Quantitative Data Analysis/Hierarchical Multiple Regression.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Effect Size
item.description: R2 = (SSEC - SSEA) ÷ SSEC In Simple Linear Regression (SLR), R2 indicates the proportion of variance in dependent variable (DV) explained (accounted for) by the model. 'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .2 (weak) r = ± .4 (moderate) r = ± .8 (strong) It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review). Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .1 (weak) r = ± .3 (moderate) r = ± .5 (strong)
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Discriminant Validity
item.description: Scores on one measure are distinct from scores on another measure that should (logically and theoretically) be independent
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Criterion Validity
item.description: Scores on one measure correlate with scores on other measures that are logically (or theoretically) related to each other Known as concurrent validity when cross-sectional and predictive validity when longitudinal or panel design
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cook's Distance
item.description: Measures the overall influence of a case on the model. Typically flagged if value is over 1. This is a measure of influence Cook's D greater than 1 is a cause for concern Cases with Cook's D greater than 1 have to be examined again because such cases are very likely to affect the regression model
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Content Validity
item.description: When the measure covers the construct of interest
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Canonical Correlation
item.description:
Canonical correlation involves the correlation between one set of X variables and another set of Y variables, using not the variables actually recorded in the data but abstract variables (' Latent Variables ') that underlie a given set of variables. It follows that there may be several Latent Variables in any set of variables as well as a number of coefficients.
Eigenvalues
Structural Equation Modeling
Cluster Analysis
Regression Analysis
Factor Analysis
Discriminant Analysis
Principal Components Analysis
LISREL
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Bivariate Analysis
item.description:
The sumultaneous analysis of two variables to determine the relationship between them. Bivariate analysis is a simple form of Multilevel Analysis.
Statistical Inference
Descriptive Statistics
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Biostatistics
item.description: The application of statistical methods to a wife range of data relating to living organisms.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Backward Stepwise Regression
item.description: Least predictive variables are trimmed
item.guid: Glossary/Research Methods/Quantitative Data Analysis/Backward Stepwise Regression.md

item.title: Sampling Error

item.title: Regression Analysis
item.description:
A term which covers a range of techniques for explaining the variability in a Dependent Variable based on the values of one or more Independent Variables.
Predicting variation in an outcome variable (y) based on changes on Predictor variables (x1, x2, etc.) Can be simple (one y and one x) or multiple (one y and many x's) Can be simultaneous (all x's predicting y at the same time) or hierarchical (x's predicting y in pre-determined blocks)
Regular Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression assumes that x and y are linearly related and are normally distributed Special cases require special analyses The sample regression coefficients are statistics; they are estimates of the population values of variable effects on Y (how much variation in y is predicted by changes in x) Different samples will yield different values for the regression coefficients
Known as Sampling Error Coefficients are estimates, and therefore always include some error. We want to minimize this error
Best Linear Unbiased Estimator (BLUE)

item.title: Bivariate Regression
item.description:
The regression of one variable on another. Assumption of Normality of Error (Testing for Normality)
Assumption of Homoscedasticity (Testing Homoscedasticity)
Assumption of Independence of Error (Testing the Independence of Error)
Assumption of No Extreme Outliers (Testing for Extreme Outliers)
Assumption of Linearity (Testing Linearity)
Note: The assumption for any statistical analysis is about the Outcome, not the Predictor . Point and click to ask SPSS to give you pop-up window for regression. (Analyze > Regression > Linear)
Move Dependent Variable to Dependent. Move Independent Variable (s) to the Independent (s). In Statistics, select Estimates (Under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (Under Residuals). Click Continue. In Plots, select Histogram and Normal Probability Plot (Under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue. In Save, select Cook's (Under Distances). Click Continue. Click OK. The simple model (i.e., mean-only model) is not very informative and has a lot of error. - Y = 𝛽0 + 𝜀 Our model-building goal is to improve prediction and thereby reduce the error. To improve prediction and reduce error, we add a predictor variable (X) to the model. This enhanced model is the beginning of a 'predictive formula' that predicts individual outcome variable scores (Y) better than just predicting the mean. To use a bivariate regression model, identify two types of variables:
Predictor, or known variable (x)
Outcome, or to-be-predicted variable (y) Regression analysis provides an equation that corresponds to a line that best predicts y scores from x scores.
The model Population Parameter will be designated with a Greek letter (β). The estimate of the population parameter, which we calculate using our sample data, is designated by the Arabic letter b. We can predict a person's score on an outcome (dependent) variable (Y-Hat) based on what we know about that person's score on a predictor (independent) variable (x). If variables x and y are related to each other, then adding x to our model improves prediction and produces less error (SSE) than the simple model generated. Here we have two competing models: You can use bivariate regression to answer the following questions about the pattern of data points and the significance of a linear equation: Is a pattern evident in a set of data points? Which equation of a straight line can best describe this pattern? Are the predictions made from this equation significant? More questions using Bivariate Regression: What is the nature of the relation between x and y? Is b statistically significant? What is the Confidence Interval for b. What is the effect size? How is the y variance partitioned between explained and unexplained? Do plots of residuals indicate violations of assumptions for bivariate linear regression? The error produced by Model C is the most error a parametric model can have. Thus, we often call this model as the simplest or null model.
We call the sum of squared errors generated by Model C the Sum of Squares Total (SST). We call the sum of squared errors by Model A SSEA. SST is almost always greater than SSEA. SST = SSEA + SSR Y-Hat = b0 + b1X Y-Hat: Predicted value of Y b0: Intercept, the value of Y when X = 0. b1: Slope, the change in Y relative to the change in X. We actually never know the true population value of parameter β; we only estimate with our data. Yi = 𝛽0 + 𝛽1Xi + 𝜀i We will calculate b1 first. Determine b0 and using b1. Conceptual Formula
Computational Formula



To estimate the error generated by this augmented model (SSEA) we need to Predict a score on Y for each subject. Find the difference between each subject's predicted and actual scores on Y. Square the differences. Add them up. Y = 10.268 - .776x + 𝜀
It is difficult to judge is an error reduction of 64.383 is a lot or a little. To help us get a sense of how much error we reduced, we express this reduction in error as a percentage of the total error (SST). The regression model explained .805 (80.5%, effect size) of the original SST in variable Y.

For the simple mean-only model, 𝛽0, was a constant equal to the mean of Y. Since the mean of Y was 6, 𝛽0 = 6. The intercept, 𝛽0, is the predicted value of Y when X is zero. Thus, if X has no meaningful value of 0, the estimated intercept is not informative. Centering the predictor of X to its mean can generate a better estimate because then the estimated 𝛽0 is now the predictor value of Y when the predictor X is its mean. Think about the 1 st year college CPA as the outcome (Y) predicted by the SAT score (X).

Y = 10.268 - .776 X + 𝜀 Y = 6 - .776 X' + 𝜀 This new regression equation shows the exact same relationship between Y and X' as we found for Y and X. If you calculate the error of this regression model, you will get the exact same SSEA Allows us to answer the following: Is a pattern evident in a set of data points? Which equation of a straight line can best describe this pattern? Are the predictions made from this equation significant? What is the nature of the relation between x and y.
Is b statistically significant? What is the Confidence Intervals (CI) for b?
What is the Effect Size ?
How is the y Variance partitioned between explained and unexplained?
Do plots of residuals indicate violations of assumptions for Bivariate Regression? “Media/Files/3. Bivariate Regression.png” could not be found. Compact Model Total Error SST (total possible error = SSEC) Augmented Model Error in Model A SSEA (error of augmented model) SST - SSEa = Explained Error SSR = Compact Model - Augmented Model OR SSR = SSEC - SSEA
Effect Size R2 = (SSEC - SSEA) ÷ SSEC Football lovers will be more confident in their GLM statistics abilities. Hypothesis: Students who report higher levels of love for football will more likely report higher levels of GLM efficacy. X: Football Y: Quant_Eff Yi (Quant_Eff) = 𝛽0 (Intercept) + 𝛽1 (Slope) Xi (Football) + 𝜀i (Residual) Hypothesis: Students' perceptions of their teachers' enthusiasm will positively predict students' engagement. Y: Student Engagement X: Teacher Enthusiasm Yi (Engagement) = 𝛽0 (Intercept) + 𝛽1 (Slope) Xi (Enthusiasm) + 𝜀i (Residual)

item.title: Best Linear Unbiased Estimator (BLUE)
item.description: Often abbreviated to BLUE, a Best Linear Unbiased Estimator is a regression line which has been computed using the least-squares criterion and where none of the assumptions are violated. It will have a smaller variance than any other estimator of the population parameter.

item.title: Variance Inflation Factor (VIF)
item.description:
The Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) is a measure of multicollinearity in regression analysis. It quantifies how much the variance of a regression coefficient is inflated due to collinearity among predictor variables. VIF = 1 → No collinearity. VIF between 1 and 5 → Moderate collinearity (acceptable). VIF > 10 → High collinearity (problematic, requires corrective action). A high VIF suggests that one independent variable is highly correlated with others, making it difficult to determine the individual effect of each predictor.
You can calculate VIF in SPSS using Multiple Linear Regression: Click Analyze → Regression → Linear. Specify Variables: Move the dependent variable to the Dependent box. Move the independent variables to the Independent(s) box. Enable Collinearity Diagnostics: Click Statistics. Check Collinearity diagnostics and Tolerance/VIF. Click Continue. Run the Analysis: Click OK. The Coefficients Table in SPSS will include two relevant columns: Tolerance: The proportion of variance in a predictor not explained by the other predictors (Tolerance = 1/VIF). VIF (Variance Inflation Factor): The degree to which variance is inflated due to multicollinearity. If VIF < 5, multicollinearity is not a major concern. If VIF > 5, review the correlation between predictors. If VIF > 10, severe multicollinearity exists, and corrective action (e.g., removing variables, combining correlated variables, or using Principal Component Analysis) may be needed. "A multiple regression was conducted to predict Y based on X1, X2, and X3. The VIF values were examined for multicollinearity, with all values below 5, indicating no severe multicollinearity concerns (X1 VIF = 1.18, X2 VIF = 3.12, X3 VIF = 11.11). However, X3 showed high collinearity (VIF > 10), suggesting a need for further analysis or model revision."
item.guid: Glossary/Research Methods/Key Concepts in Research/Variance Inflation Factor (VIF).md

item.title: Testing Homoscedasticity
item.description:
The residuals (errors) have constant Variance across all levels of Independent Variable s. How to Check Plot residuals vs. Predicted values Look for a random scatter. In SPSS: request Linear Regression Plots. Y > ZPred X > Z Resid If the scatterplot shows no overall pattern, the assumption is met.
Example Check if the spread of residuals is consistent across predicted house prices. Solution Apply transformations or use weighted least squares.

item.title: Testing for Extreme Outliers
item.description: Utilize Cook's Distance under the 'Residuals Statistics' Table If the maximum Cook's distance is below 1.0, then the assumption is met. Other tests may give a different cutoff point, but for our purposes we will use 1.0.

item.title: T-Test
item.description:
A statistical procedure designed to assess whether differences in the means of two groups reflect differences in their respective populations or are simply due to chance. Non-directional (two-tailed): To test if mean where sample came from (µ) is significantly different from hypothesized mean (µ0). H0: µ = µ0 vs. H1: µ ≠ µ0 Alternatively in terms of mean difference: H0: µ - µ0 = 0 vs. H1: µ - µ0 ≠ 0 Directional (One-Tailed): H0: µ ≤ µ0 vs. H1: µ > µ0 H0: µ ≥ µ0 vs. H1: µ < µ0 Reject H0 if tobs = (x bar - µ0) ÷ (s ÷ √n) falls into the critical region (determined by tcrit given the df) Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-sample t-test Pick variable and enter the Test Value (µ0) SPSS reports p-values for both one-sided (directional) and two-sided (non-directional) tests. However, confidence interval (CI) of mean difference is only constructed for two-sided. Set up hypotheses based on the research question. Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution? Given the confidence level 100 (1 - 𝜎)%, what is considered extreme evidence? Compared to the critical value, is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from µ0? For one-sample t-test (population σ unknown), we use Cohen’s d to report effect size. Cohen’s d = (x bar - μ0) ÷ s Recall Cohen’s d for one-sample z-test: d = (x bar - μ0) ÷ 𝜎 So, here sample SD (𝜎) is used to estimate 𝜎. Notice, unlike z or t scores, effect sizes are not affected by sample size Size of Cohen's d (by convention): Small effect: d = ± 0.2 Medium effect: d = ± 0.5 Large effect: d = ± 0.8 SPSS reports both one-sided and two-sided p-values, but only two-sided CI is reported. To obtain one-sided upper or lower confidence limits, run a test doubling the 𝛼 (alpha) level This doe snot affect the p-values reported in the output. Say if you are conducting a directional test a 95% confidence level and want to see LCL or UCL, you can change the confidence interval percentage from 95% to 90% in Options. The lower end of reported 90% CI would be 95% LCL (Lower Control Limit), and the upper end of reported 90% CI would be 95% (Upper Control Limit). Any variation detected inside the control limits probably occurred by chance. On the other hand, variation outside of the control limits likely occurred due to special causes. The upper control limit (UCL) and the lower control limit (LCL) serve as boundaries for expected deviation in data.

Control Charts A one-sample t-test was conducted at an alpha level of .05 to answer the research question: Is OSU students’ willingness to pay (WTP) for Gardyn significantly different from the retail price $899? The null hypothesis stated that WTP would not differ from the retail price. The alternative hypothesis stated that WTP would differ from the retail price. Based on a random sample of 20 OSU students, there was a mean WTP of $181.9 and a standard deviation of $231.215. Then compared against the hypothesized mean of $899, the one-sample t-test was statistically significant, t(19) = -13.87, p < .001, indicating WTP is significantly different from $899. In addition, the effect size Cohen’s d was -3.101, generally interpreted as a large effect (Cohen, 1988), indicating that there is about 3 standard deviations difference between WTP and retail price, with the WTP lower than the retail price.
7. Paired-Sample T-Test Nondirectional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly different from pre-score (µ1) H0: µ2 = µ1 vs. H1: µ2 ≠ µ1 Alternatively, in terms of mean difference: H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 The mean difference is the difference in pre- and post-scores, so a paired-sample t-test is identical to a one-sample t-test, testing the difference in scores against the hypothesized (test) value! Directional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly greater from pre-score (µ1). H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 Directional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly smaller than pre-scores (µ1): H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0 tobs = d ÷ sd-bar or d ÷ (sd ÷ √n) d is the mean difference and sd-bar is the standard error of the mean difference: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n sd is the standard deviation of the difference scores (i.e., like any other standard deviation only this one is computed from the difference scores rather than raw scores). n is the total number of pairs. Recall in one-sample t-test: tobs = ( - µ0) (s ÷ √n) Where is µ0? Given 𝛼 level, nondirectional or directional, and degree of freedom (df = n - 1), critical t can be found on the t-table (if df is available). Recall rejection region is outside of critical t('s) toward the tail (s). Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) or p < 𝛼 (SPSS) 𝛼 level is usually .05 (95% confidence level) Nondirectional: 100 (1 - 𝛼)% CI: ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sd-bar ÷ √n) To test greater (significant increase in post-scores): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% LCL: - tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar To test smaller (significant decrease in post-scores): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% UCL: + tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar DV data recorded as 2 variables (e.g., pre-score and post-score) in SPSS IV (treatment, intervention) is usually not recorded as a variable in SPSS Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test Move the two variables of interest (e.g., pre-score and post-score) to the paired variable 1 and variable 2. Notice the mean difference SPSS computes is variable 1 minus variable 2, so sometimes the sign of observed t can be confusing. However, you can easily figure out if the effect is positive or negative based on the descriptive statistics. I like to enter post-score as variable 1 and pre-score as variable 2 so I can see the change (positive or negative) from pre-score to post-score. Cohen's d = d-bar ÷ sd-bar Recall Cohen's d for one-sample t-test: d = ( - µ0) ÷ s Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ±0.2: Small effect d = ±0.5: Medium effect d = ±0.8: Large effect The pre-video and post-video negative emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 4.80 (SD = 0.926) and a post-score mean of 4.60 (SD = 1.028). Thus, negative emotion changed by -0.20 (decrease) after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly smaller than zero (significant decrease after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly lower than the pre-score, t(33) = -2.393, p = 0.011. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was -0.410. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small to medium effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the negative emotion significantly decreased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests about 0.4 standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The pre-video and post-video positive emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 3.76 (SD = 0.998) and a post-score mean of 4.82 (SD = 1.014). Thus, positive emotion increased by 1.06 after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly greater than zero (significant increase after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly higher than the pre-score, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was 1.106. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a large effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the positive emotion significantly increased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests more than one standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. Used for questions about whether the population standard mean (µ) from which we drew sample equals a specific hypothesized value (µ0). Non-directional (two-sided) or directional (one-sided) Population standard deviation (𝜎) is unknown: estimated by sample standard deviation (s). Assumptions: Observations come from a random sample, and subjects are independent of each other. Variable is measured on at least an interval level scale. Sampling distribution of the mean is normal, and CLT assures that for big samples (say 30).

item.title: Sampling
item.description:
Sampling is the process of selecting a given number of units of analysis from a population. Although in social research these units are often individuals, they do not need to be but could be households, firms, countries, or whatever. Sampling is often based on randomness to ensure representativeness, although non-random sampling might be used in some circumstances. Access

item.title: Multiple Linear Regression (MLR)
item.description:
A statistical method analyzing the linear relationship between an interval level dependent variable and two or more independent variables. Predicts a continuous dependent variable using multiple independent variables. Example: Predicting exam scores based on study hours and attendance. Analyze → Regression → Linear. Move your dependent variable to the Dependent box and predictors to the Independent(s) box. Click Statistics and select Collinearity diagnostics and Durbin–Watson. Click OK. Interpretation: R² = 0.61 indicates that 61% of the variance in exam scores is explained by the predictors. Interpretation: A significant F (p < .001) indicates the model fits significantly better than one with no predictors. Interpretation: Both predictors are significant. VIF values are acceptable (<10). The Durbin–Watson statistic (not shown here) should be near 2. "A multiple linear regression was conducted to predict exam scores from study hours and attendance. The overall model was significant, F(3,56) = 15.41, p < .001, R² = 0.61. Study hours (β = 0.45, t(56) = 6.83, p < .001) and attendance (β = -0.28, t(56) = -3.78, p = .002) were both significant predictors." MLR is used when you want to understand the relationship between one Dependent Variable and two or more Independent Variable. It is commonly applied in scenarios such as: Predicting Outcomes For example, predicting house prices based on square footage, number of bedrooms, and location. Understanding Relationships For example, analyzing how factors like advertising spend, produce price, and customer satisfaction influence sales. Controlling for Confounding Variables For example, studying the effect of education level on income while controlling for age and work experience.
In Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) multicollinearity is said to exist when two or more of the independent variables are themselves highly correlated, a situation that makes it difficult to establish the effect each has on the dependent variable. How to Check
Calculate the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF). Values above 5-10 indicate multicollinearity. Example Check if square footage and number of bedrooms are highly correlated. Solution Remove or combine correlated variables.
The relationship between the Dependent Variable and each Independent Variable is linear. How to Check Use scatterplots to visualize relationships. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot. Click Simple Scatter. Click Define.
Move your Dependent Variable (Outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your Independent Variable (Predictor) to the X-Axis If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met.
Example Plot house price against square footage to see if the relationship linear. Solution If not linear, apply transformations (e.g., log, square root)
The residuals (errors) have constant Variance across all levels of Independent Variable s. How to Check Plot residuals vs. Predicted values Look for a random scatter. In SPSS: Request Linear Regression Plots. Y > ZPred X > Z Resid If the scatterplot shows no overall pattern, the assumption is met.
Example Check if the spread of residuals is consistent across predicted house prices. Solution Apply transformations or use weighted least squares. An assessment of the normality of data is a prerequisite for many statistical tests because normal data is an underlying assumption in parametric testing. SPSS allows you to test all of these procedures within Explore command. The Explore command can be used in isolation if you are testing normality in one group or splitting your dataset into one or more groups. If you have 2 or more categorical, independent variables, the Explore command on its own is not enough and you will have to use the Split File command also. Click Analyze -> Descriptives -> Explore
Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box. Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected. Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests. When testing for normality, we are mainly interested in the Tests of Normality table and the Normal Q-Q Plots, our numerical and graphical methods to test for the normality of data, respectively.
The above table presents the results from two well-known tests of normality, namely the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test and the Shapiro-Wilk. The Shapiro-Wilk Test is more appropriate for small sample sizes (<50 samples), but can also handle sample sizes as large as 2000. If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below 0.05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.
In order to determine normality graphically, we can use the output of a normal P-P plot. If the data are normally distributed, the data points will be close to the diagonal line. If the data points stray from the line in an obvious non-linear fashion, the data are not normally distributed. If the points are generally along the diagonal, the assumption is met. If you are at all unsure of being able to correctly interpret the graph, rely on the numeric methods instead because it can take a fair bit of experience to correctly judge the normality of data based on plots.
If the histogram is approximately normal, the assumption is met. The distribution curve is normal/bell shaped. The assumption is met if the skewness and kurtosis is between +2 and -2. The Explore command on its own cannot separate the dependent variable into groups based on not one but two or more independent variables. However, we can perform this feat by using the Split File command. Click Data -> Split File Click Organize Output by Groups. Transfer the independent variables you wish to categorize the dependent variable on into the Groups Based On box. Proceed as above. Utilize Cook's Distance under the 'Residuals Statistics' Table
If the maximum Cook's distance is below 1.0, then the assumption is met. Other tests may give a different cutoff point, but for our purposes we will use 1.0.
Observations are independent of each other (no Autocorrelation) How to Check Use the Durbin-Watson test. If the Durbin-Watson test falls within the range of 1.5 - 2.5, the assumption is met. Examples
For this example, we'll say 1.482 is close enough to 1.5 and the assumption is met. Ensure house prices are not influenced by neighboring houses. Solutions
Use Time-Series Design if data is Autocorrelation. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Move Dependent Variable to Dependent. Move Independent Variable (s) to the Independent (s). In Statistics, select Estimates (Under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (Under Residuals). Click Continue. In Plots, select Histogram and Normal Probability Plot (Under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue. In Save, select Cook's (Under Distances). Click Continue. Click OK.
Dependent Y variable Block Use next and previous buttons for blocks of variables Independent (s) x-variables Method Allows you to use stepwise, never use this Always use paste to send the analysis to the syntax editor and save your work.
Include Model Fit, R-squared change, Descriptives, Part and Partial Correlations, and Collinearity Diagnostics Confidence intervals are not necessary but can be helpful.
You can save residuals as their own variables to detect multivariate outliers. Predicted values tell you what SPSS thinks the y value should be based on the x-values of the case. Residual values are how far off SPSS was
Mahalanobis distance (Mahal Distance) tells you how far away a case is from the 'cloud' of other values.

item.title: Correlation
item.description:
The statistical association between two variables measured at ordinal, interval or ratio level. Many different 'correlation co-efficients' are used as measures of association. We already know many ways to represent the association between two variables, both measured on at least an interval scale. Scatterplot Covariance sxy = (∑i = 1n (x1 - x-bar)(yi - y-bar)) ÷ n - 1 (𝜎xy for population) Pearson correlation coefficient rxy = (sxy) ÷ (sxsy) (𝜌xy for population) The correlation reflects the noisiness and direction of a linear relationship, but not the slope of that relationship, nor many aspects of non-linear relationships. To test whether the sample correlation between x and y is significantly different from zero (non-directional): H0: 𝜌 = 0 vs. H1: 𝜌 ≠ 0 Directional alternatives are also possible. Assumptions: Linearity: The Pearson correlation assumes that the relationship among x and y is a linear relationship. Independence: Units or cases are randomly sampled from the population. tobs = r√(n - 2) ÷ (1 - r2) tcrit: Given the 𝛼 level, t distribution with degrees of freedom (df = n - 2) Reject H0 if tobs > tcrit (or for negative values: tobs < tcrit) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < 𝛼 APA Style Writing Template: A Pearson correlation coefficient was computed to assess the linear relationship between x and y. There was a (weak / moderate / strong negative / positive) correlation between x and y, r (df) = (p-value). Notice: No need to report t. Restricting the range of scores on one or both variables will reduce the strength of a correlation. If the size of the standard deviation for one variable is reduced, everything else being equal, then the size of correlations with other variables will also be reduced. In other words, we need sufficient variation for a relationship to be evidenced through the correlation coefficient value. HS GPA and ACT example: The strength of correlation between GPA and ACT will be lessened if we only focus on the graduates with summa cum laude (weighted GPA 4.2 or above). Correlation means the variables are related in some way, but correlations alone should not be used to infer cause. A high correlation between x and y might be a result of: x causes y y causes x A third variable z is causing both x and y (or even more variables are involved). Causality is not easy to prove. Application of complex statistical methods is not evidence for causality! Causation (x -> y) can only be inferred (formalized by the 19 th-century philosopher John Stuart Mill) if: x proceeded y x was related to y We can find no other plausible alternative explanation for the effect on y other than x. 'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .2 (weak) r = ± .4 (moderate) r = ± .8 (strong) It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review). Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .1 (weak) r = ± .3 (moderate) r = ± .5 (strong) Correlation does not imply causation. With proper literature review and research design, however we can investigate how one variable (x or IV) explains the variability (variance) in the other variable (y or DV). If x is indeed a significant predictor of y, we can use x to predict y. Still a bivariate analysis, but with a different goal in mind. For example, the school district might want to use GPA to explain the variable in ACT scores and use GPA to predict ACT.
Here we have only one predictor (IV) in the model: Simple Linear Regression (SLR). You will learn regression models with multiple predictors, multiple linear regression (MLR), in more advanced stats classes. Regression means you are trying to find a pattern between x and y. You are using x to predict y. We are only using one.
If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x. HS GPA and ACT example: r = .698 Square it: r2 = (. 698)2 ≈ .487 This indicates 48.7% of the variance in ACT scores can be explained (or accounted for) by GPA. Recall r ranges from -1 to 1. What does it mean for the range of r2? Recall 'ballpark' effect size: Weak (|r| ≥ .2) Weak (r2 ≥ .04 or 4%) Moderate (|r| ≥ .4) Moderate (r2 ≥ .16 or 16%) Strong (|r| ≥ .8) Strong (r2 ≥ .64 or 64%) xi: IV data point for subject i yi: DV data point for subject i yi: Expected/predicted value for subject i (i.e., the regression line)
𝛽0: Intercept (Constant) 𝛽1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit) Finding b0 and b1 (regression coefficients) for the regression line:
Best estimates for b's are the ones that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. Working with the squared values, our goal is to find estimate b0 and b1 to minimize the error sum of squares: SSE = The optimal solution: b0 = y-hat - b1x-bar Regression line goes through both means of x and y! The slope is determined by the correlation between x and y with a scale of y per change in x. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear Define DV and IV (one IV for SLR) Usually you'd already review descriptive statistics and correlations before running a regression, but you can also ask SPSS to report Descriptive in the Statistics option. Many other options are for MLR only. The default SPSS output has 3 sections: Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model) ANOVA Table (Model significance) Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line) Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts: What we can explain by the model (regression) What we still cannot explain (error) Regression sum of squares (SSR) Error Sum of Squares (SSE) Total Sum of Squares (SSTO) SSTO = SSR + SSE SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit. R2 = (SSR) ÷ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE ÷ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2 In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive) In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy | Omnibus: Comprising several items "Congress passed an omnibus anticrime package." The omnibus test is used to evaluate the significance of overall regression model. Statistics used to conduct the omnibus test are available in the ANOVA table. Many different (equivalent) ways to represent the omnibus test, but they are asking the same question: Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV? Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually α=. 05). General idea: Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)! H0: β1 = 0 H1: β1 ≠ 0 H0: y-hat = y-bar H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model) H0: ρ = 0 (ρ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R) H1: ρ > 0 H0: ρ2 = 0 H1: ρ2 > 0 Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2) Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < α For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.

item.title: Bayesian Statistics
item.description:
A method of statistical inference named after Thomas Bayes, an 18th-century English mathematician. The method involves working backwards from effect to cause, by estimating the conditional probability of a cause given that certain events have occurred. Bayesian inference involves using new information, called the posterior probability, to revise earlier estimates of probability, called Prior Probability.

item.title: Autocorrelation
item.description: Many statistical procedures depend on the assumption that modelling errors are independent of one other. In the xontext of time-series research designs where, for example, repeated observations are made of the same entity such as an individual or country, this assumption is often not met. Where this occurs the errors are said to be autocorrelated. Heteroscedasticity

item.title: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
item.description:
In general, a family of statistical methods that deal with the differences in the means of a variable across groups of observations. More specifically, a statistical procedure used to test for the difference between two sample means in situations where the Dependent Variable are continuous and the Independent Variable are categorical. Used to test if two variables are related. It compares means by looking for variability between those means and tells you how much variation there is between groups and within groups:
